This is not correct. You only have one digit accuracy in the mass of the sun, so you only have one digit accuracy in the number of protons. The answer is 1 x 10^57, not 1.195 x 10^57. The ".195"  are garbage digits that you do not actually know.
Using a scientific calculator, use E for order of magnitudes, not e. I could be wrong, but I think there is a difference.

I know this is kindof an old video, and you guys might already now the procedure to solve this without a calculator.... I hope this might be helpful to someone here though...
To solve that division without a calculator is actually very simple.
When dividing two numbers in scientific notation, you can divide the two significant digit
figures (2 and 1.673 in this case), and arrive at a power-of-ten by subtracting exponents (30 minus -27 in this case).
As oposed to division, when multiplying two numbers in scientific notation, you can multiply the two significant
digit figures and arrive at a power-of-ten by adding exponents.
The answer is 1.195 ×10 power of 57

In fact, the sun is almost entirely made of hydrogen plasma, which is mostly protons "floating" in an "electron-soup". Since the mass of an electron is a tiny fraction of the mass of a proton, we can say that 10^57 protons is a good approximation of the real number of protons in the sun. :)

You're ignoring significant digits. As you have worked the problem, you should have written the quotient with one significant digit. Or perhaps you should have used 1.989 x 10^30 kg for the mass of the sun. It's as egregious as using pi = 3.14 in a problem that has more than three significant digits.
And now, we've finally got an answer to what would happen to the sun if it were entirely made out of protons: what-if.xkcd.com/140
actually, its a 1 followed by a 1 followed by a 9 followed by a 5 followed by 54 zeros. It makes a large difference.

Actually you can do this problem by dividing 2 by 1.673 and then simply subtracting the exponent from the divisor by the one from the numerator.  Since the exponent in the divisor is negative, you get 30 - (-27) = 30 + 27 = 57.  So you get 1.195 x 10^57 which just illustrates another of the awesome uses of the scientific notation format.  Since you're dealing with the values separately you can solve the problem piecemeal and then put everything back together.

That's a very nice explanation, maybe it would have been easier to understand how you came up with the division part if you would have wrote down a little proportion before. Something like this:
1 proton - 1.6e-27 Kg
x protons - 2e30 Kg
Then x*1.6e-27=1*2e30 and then x is simply equal to (1 proton * 2e30)/1.6e-27.
where division of powers of ten's can be treated as a subtraction. 30-(-27)=30+27=57
and 2/1.6=1.2 where we obtain the answer 1.2e57

Or do it in your head or on paper. You can work the power of 10 out by doing 10^(30-(27)) (a^x/a^y = a^(x-y)) and 2/1.673 you can leave as that or multiply everything by 1000 and work it out like that. So the answer can be written as (2/1.673)*10^57

exponents tell you the place where the decimals begin. So if you say 1.053*10^3 means the decimal place 3 spaces to the right = 1053.0 or 0.157*10^-3 means decimal place 3 places to the left = 0.000157

So the answer to the question is 1.195*10^57 = 119500000000000000000000...0000 (54  zeros)
but he only measured to 1 S.F. so in order to keep the answer precise (not accurate) he had to only use 1 S.F
Or you can use basic maths and minus the powers like 30-(-27)

he isn't asking how many proton's would FIT in the sun, as if they could all be squished into the spherical shape that is the sun, he is asking how many there would need to be to make up the mass of the sun. This has absolutely nothing to do with the volume of either items.
also if you just use exponential laws for the powers of ten, and divide the coefficients it will still work out.
